questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents to the clinic for evaluation of her fertility status. She has been trying to conceive for over a year without success. Which of the following is the single best test for assessing her ovarian reserve?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Anti-Müllerian hormone (AMH)

 

Explanation:

  • Anti-Müllerian hormone (AMH) levels correlate with the number of antral follicles in the ovaries and provide a direct measure of ovarian reserve.
  • AMH is less variable throughout the menstrual cycle and is considered the most reliable single test for assessing ovarian reserve.

 

 

Tests for Ovarian Reserve:

Test Name

Description

Key Points

Anti-Müllerian Hormone (AMH)

A hormone produced by ovarian antral follicles.
  • Blood test reflecting the remaining quantity of eggs.
  • Not affected by the menstrual cycle.
  • The single best test for assessing her ovarian reserve

Antral Follicle Count (AFC)

Ultrasound count of the small follicles (antral follicles) within the ovaries.
  • Direct visual assessment.
  • Can vary with the cycle.
  • Baseline assessment and monitoring.

Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH)

Measures the level of FSH, which stimulates the growth of ovarian follicles.
  • Blood test done on day 3 of the menstrual cycle.
  • Initial screening of ovarian function.

Estradiol (E2)

Measures the level of estradiol, an estrogen produced by growing follicles.
  • Blood test done on day 3 of the menstrual cycle.
  • High levels can mask high FSH levels, so they are used in conjunction with FSH.

Inhibin B

Measures the level of inhibin B, which reflects the number of antral follicles.
  • Blood test on day 5 of the menstrual cycle.

Clomiphene Citrate Challenge Test (CCCT)

Measures FSH and estradiol before and after taking clomiphene citrate.
  • Two blood tests: day 3 and day 10.
  • Higher FSH levels on day 10 indicate lower reserve.
  • Used for detailed functional assessment.

 

Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) on day 3 (Option A): Elevated levels of FSH on the third day of the menstrual cycle can indicate diminished ovarian reserve. However, FSH levels can fluctuate and be influenced by various factors, making it a less reliable single test.

 

 

Estradiol on day 3 (Option B): Elevated estradiol levels on the third day of the menstrual cycle can suggest a diminished ovarian reserve. However, like FSH, estradiol levels can be variable and influenced by other factors.

 

 

Serum inhibin levels on day 5 (Option D): Inhibin B levels can reflect the size and function of the ovarian follicle pool, but they can be more variable and less consistent than AMH.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding acrosome reaction?

choices.text: Occurs due to the release of hormones such as testosterone.
Results in the formation of new sperm cells.
Mediated by the influx of potassium ions into the sperm cell.
Causes the release of enzymes for zona pellucida penetration.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Causes the release of enzymes for zona pellucida penetration.

 

Explanation:

Acrosome reaction causes the release of enzymes like acrosin for penetration of zona pellucida.

 

Acrosome Reaction:

  • The activation of acrosomal membranes causes the release of enzymes, such as hyaluronidase, hydrolytic enzymes, proacrosin, and acrosin, for zona pellucida penetration.
  • Involves fusion of sperm plasma membrane with outer acrosomal membrane.
  • It helps the sperm digest zona pellucida and fuse with the oocyte.
  • It occurs due to calcium influx.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an event of capacitation?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Acrosin is released

 

Explanation:

Acrosin is an enzyme released during acrosome reaction, not capacitation. The acrosomal reaction leads to the release of acrosomal lytic enzymes which help sperm penetrate zona pellucida and enter into the oocyte.

 


Capacitation:

  • Physiochemical change in sperm leads to hypermotility and fertilisation capability.
  • It occurs in the female genital tract.
  • Occurs in the genital tract over 2-6 hours before fertilisation.
  • Involves cyclic AMP-dependent phosphorylation.
  • There is an increase in intracellular pH, calcium influx and hydrogen ion efflux - Hyperpolarisation of the sperm plasma membrane.

questions.text:
Match the following statements with the correct technique of sperm extraction.

Statements:


	Butterfly needle into testes and fluid aspirated
	Direct vision of epididymis is required
	Testicular parenchyma dissected under the microscope
	Sperm aspirated through a needle in the epididymis


Techniques:


	Percutaneous Epididymal Sperm Aspiration- PESA
	Testicular Sperm Aspiration- TESA
	Microsurgical Epidydimal Sperm Aspiration- MESA
	Microsurgical testicular sperm extraction- Microdissection TESE
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a

Explanation:

Patients diagnosed with azoospermia can achieve fatherhood through intra-cytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI), for which sperm is retrieved using various techniques.

Technique

Description

Microsurgical Epididymal Sperm Aspiration (MESA)
  • Use of operating microscope.
  • Epididymis exposed.

Percutaneous Epididymal Sperm Aspiration (PESA)
  • Needle punctures epididymis.
  • The procedure is guided by palpation; multiple attempts may be necessary.

Testicular Sperm Aspiration (TESA)

Butterfly needle aspiration into testicular substance.

Microsurgical testicular sperm extraction- Microdissection TESE
  • Tunica incised, testicular parenchyma dissected under a microscope.
  • Selective biopsy of promising tubules.

questions.text: Which of the following is the testicular cause of infertility?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Kartagener syndrome

Explanation:

Kartagener syndrome causes abnormal ciliary structure or function leading to decreased ciliary motility, resulting in infertility due to testicular aetiology. In females, it leads to immotile cilia in the fallopian tube leading to infertility.

 

Male Infertility Causes:

Pretesticular

Testicular

Post testicular
  • Kallmann syndrome (Option C)
  • Hyperprolactinaemia
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Varicocele
  • Absent germ cells
  • Cryptorchidism
  • Orchitis
  • Chromosomal defect (Klinefelter syndrome)
  • Kartagener syndrome
  • Young syndrome (Option A) (obstructive azoospermia due to functional obstruction of sperm transportation in epididymis)
  • Mycoplasma genitalis
  • Prostatitis
  • Vesiculitis
  • Congenital absence of vas deferens (cystic fibrosis)

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an indication for performing ICSI with In-Vitro Fertilisation?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Donor oocyte IVF

Explanation: 

Intracytoplasmic Sperm Injection

The technique involves direct injection of a single live sperm into the cytoplasm of the oocyte, thereby bypassing limitations imposed by sperm motility and defects in capacitation, acrosome reaction &/or sperm binding to the zona pellucida.

The principle indication of ICSI is male factor infertility. It should be offered if the semen analysis shows  < 2 million motile sperms, <5% motility or if surgically retrieved sperms are used. (threshold values vary among centres). Some centres also offer ICSI with teratospermia (<4% normal morphological forms).

In the absence of a male factor ICSI offers no advantage over conventional IVF; however ICSI is also being offered in cases of prior failed fertilization with conventional IVF attempts, unexplained infertility, diminished ovarian reserve.

In-Vitro Fertilization:

Aspect

Description

Indications
  • Fallopian tubes blocked or absent
  • Unexplained infertility
  • Endometriosis
  • Oligospermia or azoospermia
  • Advanced reproductive age
  • Fertility preservation
  • Failed ovulation induction
  • Ovarian failure (donor oocyte IVF)
  • Müllerian agenesis (no uterus)
  • Women with genetic risks

Principal Steps
  • Downregulation using GnRH agonist
  • Controlled ovarian stimulation (COS)
  • Monitoring of follicular growth
  • Oocyte retrieval
  • Fertilization in vitro (conventional IVF or ICSI)
  • Transfer of gametes or embryos
  • Luteal support with progesterone

questions.text: All of the following are indications for intrauterine insemination except:
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Asherman syndrome

Explanation:

  • Intrauterine insemination (IUI) will be ineffective in a patient with Asherman syndrome, causing infertility.
  • IUI is done by introducing healthy motile sperms via a thin catheter transcervical into the uterine cavity at the time of anticipated ovulation

 

Asherman Syndrome:

  • Intrauterine synechiae → Inseminating the uterine cavity is ineffective.
  • Prior adhesiolysis can be done before trying IUI.
  • Not fit for surgery: Alternates are surrogacy and uterine transplantation.

 

Indications for IUI

C/I (Prior correctional treatment required)
  • Cervical factors infertility: Anti-sperm antibodies in cervical mucous (Option A).
  • Mild-moderate male factors: Anejaculation, anorgasmia, retrograde ejaculation (Option B).
  • Unexplained infertility (Option C).
  • Uterine factors: Fibroids, endometrial polyp, intrauterine adhesions.
  • Tubal factors: Occlusion.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for ovulation induction in women with PCOS?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Letrozole

Explanation:

Letrozole, an aromatase inhibitor, is the drug of choice for ovulation induction.

 

Letrozole:

  • Blocks ovarian conversion of androgen into estrogen (by inhibiting aromatase).
  • Reduced estradiol → reduced negative feedback over the pituitary gland → increased FSH secretion -> ovulation induction.
  • Dose: 2.5 to 7 mg/day, from the 2nd to the 6th day of menstruation
  • Advantages over clomiphene citrate (selective oestrogen receptor modulator):
    • Higher pregnancy rates.
    • Lesser chances of side effects.
  • Side effects: might cause
    • Multifetal gestation
    • Congenital cardiac & bony deformities (inconsistent data).

 

Alternate drug of the same class: Anastrozole.

questions.text: A middle-aged female who initially presented with difficulty in conception is diagnosed with PCOS, for which she is prescribed clomiphene citrate to induce ovulation. All of the following is true regarding this drug except?

choices.text: It has both estrogen agonist and antagonist properties
Similar effect irrespective of starting at day 2 or day 5 of menstruation
Endometrial thickness should be <8 mm before commencement
Multifetal gestation can occur as an adverse effect

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Endometrial thickness should be <8 mm before commencement

 

Explanation:

Endometrial thickness should be ensured as <5 mm before starting the therapy. Absence of ovarian cysts/follicles >20mm should also be ensured. These indicate a reduction in estrogen activity.

 

 

Clomiphene Citrate:

  • Selective estrogen receptor modulator - has both oestrogen agonist & (predominantly) antagonist properties (Option A)
  • Anti-estrogen → reduces negative feedback over pituitary and hypothalamus → increases secretion of GnRH & FSH.
  • Indication: Type II anovulatory infertility (normogonadotropic hypogonadism) 
  • Clomiphene citrate is ineffective in hypogonadotropic hypogonadism because it needs a functional HPO axis to increase FSH secretion. Thus, serum FSH levels should be checked before starting treatment in amenorrheic women. Additionally, ovarian cysts should be ruled out to avoid confusion with growing follicles.
  • Dose: 50mg -100mg, can start on either day between the 2nd and 6th days of menstruation (Option B) (up to 250 mg/day if not responding).
  • Reduced response: Corticosteroids as an adjunct can be given.
  • Side effects:
    • Hot flushes.
    • Pelvic discomfort.
    • Scotoma.
    • Multifetal gestation (Option D).
    • Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome.
    • Anti-endometrial effect.

questions.text: The gynaecology team of a patient with infertility decides to assess the anatomy of her reproductive tract to look for any adhesions or blocks. She is also suspected to have endometriosis. Which of the following will be the ideal investigation of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Laparohysteroscopy

Explanation:

Laparohysteroscopy:

  • 3 components (rationale on why it is the best choice):
    • Laparoscopy: Tubal anatomy + look out for tubal blocks by external factors + endometriosis.
    • Hysteroscopy: Uterine anatomy + look out for intrauterine adhesions.
    • Chromopertubation: A patency check is done by injecting methylene blue into the tubes.

 

Hysterosalpingography (Option A) is limited to evaluating tubal patency and the uterine cavity. It cannot assess external tubal blocks or diagnose endometriosis.

 

Pelvic MRI (Option C): While MRI can detect deep infiltrating endometriosis and pelvic masses, it cannot evaluate tubal patency or provide a direct view of the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes.

 

Diagnostic laparoscopy (Option D) cannot help visualise the uterine cavity.

questions.text: Identify the procedure done to assess infertility, which is given below.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Hysterosalpingography

 

Explanation:

The above image shows hysterosalpingography with normal uterine filling and bilateral patent tubes.

 

Hysterosalpingography (HSG):

  • Visualising the uterine cavity & fallopian tubes by retrograde injection of radiocontrast dye to identify filling defects & blocks.

Preparation
  • NSAID 30 minutes before to prevent tubal spasm.
  • Paracervical block in patients with cervical stenosis.

4 phases of radiographic images taken
  • Pre-contrast preliminary.
  • During contrast filling.
  • Contrast spillage into peritoneum.
  • During deflation and withdrawal.

Contraindications
  • Acute pelvic infections.
  • Active uterine bleeding.
  • Allergic to iodine.
  • Pregnancy.

Doxycycline can be given
  • If dilated tubes are identified (indicating previous pelvic infection).
  • As prophylaxis to prevent infections post-HSG.

Complications
  • Pelvic discomfort.
  • Uterine perforation.
  • Vasovagal reactions.
  • Dye allergy.
  • Intravascular dissemination of the dye.

Saline infusion sonography (Option A) or sonosalpingography uses ultrasound to visualise the uterus & tubes while simultaneously injecting saline (not radiocontrast dye) retrograde into the uterus.

 

Sonoelastography (Option C) is used to assess soft tissue stiffness.

 

Contrast-enhanced sonography (Option D) combines intravenous contrast injection & ultrasonographic examination.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with infertility. Laboratory tests reveal low levels of luteinising hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH). Which of the following is the most likely cause of his infertility?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Hyperprolactinemia

 

Explanation:

Hyperprolactinemia inhibits the secretion of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) and reduces LH and FSH levels, affecting normal testicular function and spermatogenesis.

 

Causes of Azoospermia:

1. Pre-testicular (central): endocrine disorders (low LH and FSH)
  • Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism/ Kallman syndrome
  • Endocrine: Hyperprolactinemia (Option C), obesity, thyroid disorder
  • Drugs: Antihypertensives, Antipsychotics

2. Testicular (peripheral): Intrinsic disorders (High FSH and LH)
  • Genetic disorders:
    • Klinefelter syndrome (Most common) (Option B)
    • Immotile cilia (Kartagener) syndrome
  • Varicocele: Most common reversible cause (Option A)
  • Undescended testes
  • Testicular torsion
  • Mumps orchitis
  • Heat exposure: Miners
  • Toxins: smoking, radiation, drug abuse
  • Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia

3. Post-testicular: (Normal LH and FSH)
  • Congenital: Absent vas deferens (cystic fibrosis), Young’s syndrome
  • Obstruction: Epididymal and Ejaculatory duct obstruction (Option D)
  • Acquired: Genital TB, gonorrhoea
  • Surgical: herniorrhaphy, vasectomy, bladder neck surgery
  • Other: Retrograde ejaculation, hypospadias

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient presents to the clinic for evaluation of infertility. A premenstrual endometrial biopsy is planned. When should it be performed to maximise diagnostic accuracy?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Days 21-23 of the menstrual cycle

 

Explanation:

  • Days 21-23 of the menstrual cycle fall in the mid-luteal phase, typically around 7-10 days post-ovulation.
  • The endometrium during this time is in the secretory phase, characterised by maximal glandular activity and stromal oedema, making it the optimal time to assess endometrial receptivity and potential luteal phase defects.
  • Plasma progesterone levels are also measured on these days of the menstrual cycle.

questions.text: What should the serum progesterone levels be on day 21 to indicate that ovulation has occurred?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) 3-10 ng/mL 

Explanation:

Serum progesterone levels on day 21 of a 28-day menstrual cycle are used to assess whether ovulation has occurred. Normally, progesterone levels rise after ovulation due to the corpus luteum formation. The peak progesterone levels typically occur around 7 days after ovulation.

Progesterone Levels

Implication

<3 ng/ml

Ovulation has not occurred.

3-10 ng/ml

Ovulation has likely occurred.

>20 ng/ml

It can also indicate ovulation, but this is not the typical level expected on day 21 post-ovulation.

questions.text: All are true about Y chromosome microdeletions except?

choices.text: Microdeletions in the AZFb region typically result in mild forms of male infertility.
Microdeletions in the AZFc region are the most common.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Microdeletions in the AZFb region typically result in mild forms of male infertility.

 

Explanation:

Microdeletions in the AZFb region do not typically result in mild forms of male infertility; deletions in this region are associated with severe forms of male infertility, often resulting in azoospermia (absence of sperm in semen).

 

Y Chromosome Microdeletions

  • Refers to specific deletions of genetic material on the Y chromosome, particularly in regions critical for spermatogenesis (sperm production).
  • These deletions are significant because they can disrupt the normal process of sperm formation.
  • Location and Clinical Impact:

 

  • Typically, it occurs in three specific regions located on the long arm (q arm) at region Yq11.23.
    • AZFa deletion: Oligozoospermia or azoospermia.
    • AZFb deletion: Oligozoospermia or azoospermia. (Most Severe).
    • AZFc deletion: Impaired spermatogenesis; the phenotype varies and can range from mild to severe infertility (Most Common and mildest).

Note: Short arm (p arm): sex-determining region (SRY gene).

  • Genetic testing methods used for Y microdeletions:
    • Multiplex-polymerase chain reaction (PCR)
    • Array comparative genomic hybridization (aCGH)
    • Next-generation sequencing (NGS) technologies
    • Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH)
    • Cell-free fetal DNA
    • Chromosomal microarray

questions.text: In a couple seeking fertility treatment, the male partner undergoes a semen analysis, which reveals normal sperm count, motility, and morphology. However, further testing shows high sperm DNA fragmentation. What is the significance of sperm DNA fragmentation in this context?

choices.text: It indicates a higher likelihood of successful natural conception.
It suggests no relation to IVF and ICSI Planning.
It may lead to decreased embryo quality and increased risk of miscarriage.
It implies a hormonal imbalance affecting sperm production.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) It may lead to decreased embryo quality and increased risk of miscarriage.

 

Explanation:

High sperm DNA fragmentation is linked to poor embryo development, lower implantation rates, and an increased risk of miscarriage. DNA fragmentation can compromise sperm quality, affecting embryo development post-fertilization.

 

Sperm DNA Fragmentation:

  • It refers to breaks or lesions in the DNA strands within sperm cells.
  • Causes:
    • Advanced paternal age.
    • Varicocele.
    • Infections: Genital tract infections.
    • Lifestyle Factors: Smoking, poor diet, and toxins.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Reactive oxygen species (ROS) from the above-mentioned causes can damage sperm DNA by inducing breaks in the DNA strands.
  • Significance:
    • High DNA fragmentation levels can impair sperm’s ability to fertilise an egg and result in lower pregnancy rates.
    • Poor DNA integrity can lead to abnormal embryo development and reduced implantation rates.
    • Increased DNA fragmentation is associated with higher rates of recurrent miscarriages and birth defects.
    • Assists in predicting outcomes of assisted reproductive techniques like in vitro fertilisation (IVF) and intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI).
  • Tests:

Sperm Chromatin Structure Assay (SCSA)

Measures the susceptibility of sperm DNA to acid-induced denaturation.

TUNEL Assay (Terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase dUTP Nick End Labeling)

Detects DNA strand breaks by labelling the fragmented DNA ends.

Comet Assay (Single Cell Gel Electrophoresis)

Measures DNA strand breaks in individual sperm cells.

Sperm Chromatin Dispersion (SCD) Test

Evaluates the extent of sperm DNA fragmentation based on the dispersion of DNA loops after acid denaturation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with complaints of infertility and discomfort in the scrotal area. His semen analysis reveals a volume of 3.0 mL, a concentration of 20 million/mL, a total sperm count of 60 million and leukocytes of 1.5 million/mL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Epididymitis

 

Explanation:

Epididymitis is the most prevalent underlying cause of leukocytospermia, as suggested by the patient's increased sperm leukocyte count (>1 million/ml).

 

Leukocytospermia or Pyospermia:

  • Presence of >1 million/ml leukocytes in the semen.
  • Indicates underlying infection or inflammation in the male reproductive tract.
    • Infections: epididymitis, prostatitis, and urethritis.
      • Common pathogens: Chlamydia, Ureaplasma, Mycoplasma.
    • Other conditions: sexually transmitted infections, varicocele, testicular torsion, and erectile dysfunction.
  • Treatment: Doxycycline or erythromycin for 4-6 weeks.

questions.text:
Match the following semen analysis terms with their correct definitions:


	
		
			
			1. Aspermia
			
			
			a. Reduced sperm motility
			
		
		
			
			2. Azoospermia
			
			
			b. Complete absence of semen
			
		
		
			
			3. Asthenozoospermia
			
			
			c. Absence of sperm in the semen
			
		
		
			
			4. Necrozoospermia
			
			
			d. High percentage of dead sperm in the semen
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) 1:b, 2:c, 3:a, 4:d

Explanation: 

Condition

Definition

Aspermia

Complete absence of semen

Azoospermia

Absence of sperm in the semen

Asthenozoospermia

Reduced sperm motility

Necrozoospermia

Higher percentage of dead/ non-viable sperm in the semen

Hypospermia

Low semen volume (<1.4 ml)

Oligospermia

Sperm count <16 million per ml

Severe oligospermia

Sperm count <5 million per ml

Polyzoospermia

Sperm count >350 million per ml

Teratozoospermia

>70% sperms with abnormal morphology

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male presents to the clinic unable to conceive for over a year without success. He has no significant medical history and a semen analysis is performed with the following results. What does the analysis report indicate?


	
		
			
			Volume: 1.8 mL

			pH: 7.2

			Sperm concentration: 12 million/mL

			Total motility: 42%

			Progressive motility: 34%

			Morphology: 6% normal forms

			White blood cells: 0.5 million/mL
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Oligospermia

 

Explanation:

Oligospermia is defined as low sperm concentration in the ejaculate (<16 million sperm per ml of semen).

 

Semen Analysis and Normal Values:

  • First investigation for infertility in males.
  • Performed after 1 year of unprotected intercourse without conception or earlier if there are known risk factors for infertility.
  • Abstain: 2-7 days.
  • Analysis: Within 1 hour on the liquefied semen (takes 20-30 min).

 

Parameters

Normal (Normozoospermia)

(WHO 2021 Guidelines)

Volume

> 1.4 ml

pH

7.2-8.0

Concentration

At least 16 million/ ml

Total count

39 million/ejaculate

Total Motility

42% or more

Progressive motility

30% or more

Morphology (most important)

4% or more

Pus cells (WBC)

1-2 million/ml

Viability

54% or more

Note:

  • Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia (OATZ) means all parameters are subnormal, as seen in varicocele and smoking.
  • The most important parameters in sperm analysis are Morphology > Motility > Concentration.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the WHO classification of anovulation?

choices.text: Type I includes Kallman syndrome, which is associated with high FSH levels.
Type III includes women with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.
Type I includes women with hyperprolactinemia.
Type II includes women with normogonadotropic normoestrogenic anovulation.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Type II includes women with normogonadotropic normoestrogenic anovulation.

 

Explanation:

WHO group II includes women with normogonadotropic normoestrogenic anovulation.

 

WHO Classification for Anovulation:

Type/ Group

Features

Hormone levels

I (Option A)

(Central)
  • Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism
    • Sheehan syndrome, Kallmann syndrome

Low LH & FSH

Low estrogen

II (Option D)
(Peripheral)
  • Normogonadotropic hypogonadism
    • PCOD (most common)

Normal LH & FSH (abnormal ratio)

Normal estrogen

III (Option B)

(Low estrogen)
  • Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism
    • Premature ovarian failure: Radiation, chemotherapy, galactosemia

High LH & FSH

Low estrogen

 

Note: Hyperprolactinaemia (Option C) suppresses GnRH production and is classified as a separate cause (Type IV).

questions.text: A 35-year-old obese woman has been trying to conceive for over a year without success. She reports a history of irregular menstrual cycles. She has no history of pelvic inflammatory disease and USG shows no uterine abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her infertility?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Ovulatory dysfunction

Explanation:

Ovulatory Dysfunction (PCOS) is the most common cause of female infertility in this patient with a history of irregular menstrual cycles and obesity.

Causes of Female Infertility:

1. Ovarian
  • Anovulation: PCOD (most common), hyperprolactinemia.
  • Kallman syndrome
  • Premature ovarian failure: Radiation, chemotherapy, galactosemia

2. Tubal (Blockage)
  • Recurrent PID, TB pelvis, Salpingitis
  • Endometriosis
  • Tubectomy
  • Kartagener syndrome

3. Uterine
  • Fibroid (M/C: Submucosal), Endometrial polyp
  • Ashermann syndrome
  • Chronic endometritis (Clamydia)
  • Diethylstilbestrol (DES): T shape uterus
  • Septate uterus

4. Cervical
  • Cervicitis
  • Cervical stenosis
  • Antisperm antibodies

5. Vaginal
  • Atresia, transverse vaginal septum

6. Miscellaneous
  • Alcohol, Smoking
